Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2015 06:43PM Beasly wrote: Hugs to you and your whole family!  If the Doctor said she can live 5-20 years, remember that they are coming up with new and better treatments all the time.  Ten years or even five years from now there is no telling what they will be able to do.  This is not "positive thinking", it's the truth.  If you start looking around at the internet medical sites, you might get yourself in a twist because, well I do it all the time.  But then I start googling new treatments and the future of breast cancer and it's amazing what is around the corner.  She's a lucky woman already to have such loving children.  Keep us posted, and give us a shout any time you are worried or overwhelmed.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2015 08:06PM - edited Feb 3, 2015 08:12PM by Beasly My sister had a lump removed 8 years ago, chemo and then radiation.  She is a proud "survivor" who thinks that I will also be a "survivor" though it's in my lungs and bones.  She did not ask my consent before telling extended family far and wide about my diagnosis, because she knew I would not have given it.  So she inserted herself in such a way that everyone talked to her, and then she would relay messages "So and so said they are thinking about you".... She has criticized me for my "negative attitude" for simply saying the truth.  We have fought constantly since my diagnosis because she doesn't want to hear anything she can't attest to herself.  You see, this is about her.  And she gets to decide what is and isn't happening in the world.  She disagrees with every word I say.  I know what my prognosis is, and I am going to stare it in the face every day.  If I could pretend it's not there, maybe I would, but I am not that kind of person.  I'm not depressed, and in fact am a much happier person minute by minute, than she ever has been.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2015 01:21PM - edited Jul 30, 2015 01:21PM by Beasly Hi Tshire, I wonder if you aren't a little too hard on yourself for being scared. There's a Zen (or maybe Buddhist) saying that goes something like this "the soft grass that bows to the storm is stronger than the branch that strains against it and snaps". I don't think you can push your fear away. I think you have to sit with it, and tolerate it. Your fear will subside when it's ready, and not a minute sooner. If you are scared be scared, if you are sad be sad, happy be happy. It's reasonable to be scared, and probably means you are perfectly mentally healthy. If you try to stop feeling fear, it's like trying to make yourself crazy. It's sane to be scared about this. Don't make yourself crazy being afraid of being afraid. If that makes sense. :-) I think there is every reason to think you will go through this dramatic year and then the Dr. will send you on your way for a full life of good health. You now know to pay attention to your body, your health, and will have this experience for the rest of your life, and experience is always enlightening. Everyone is different, so I can only hope that my thoughts are helpful to you. I'm thinking of you and wishing you and all my sisters the best.
